Introduction

Abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) is a common gynecological issue that refers to uterine bleeding that is irregular in volume, duration, or timing.  It can affect women of all ages and can be due to both structural and nonstructural causes.



This article focuses on causes and basic evaluation of AUB; additional information on the various etiologies can be found in additional articles.

Terminology



The menstrual cycle has a set of parameters that help define normal menses.  Patients typically have menstrual bleeding every 24-38 days, <8 days of bleeding, and blood loss that does not interfere with daily activities (classically defined as <80 mL of blood).



Patients with AUB have:



  • Irregular menstrual blood loss volume:  either heavy or light bleeding
  • Irregular timing:  absent, infrequent, or frequent menstrual cycles (eg, amenorrhea, menstrual cycles <24 or >38 days)
  • Irregular duration:  usually prolonged (>8 days of bleeding)
  • Intermenstrual bleeding:  regular menses plus bleeding between menstrual cycles (eg, postcoital bleeding)

Causes



Causes of AUB can be categorized into structural and nonstructural factors, which are classified using the PALM-COEIN system.

Structural causes: PALM



  • Polyp:  endometrial or cervical polyps; typically causes intermenstrual bleeding
  • Adenomyosis:  endometrial glands and stroma within the myometrium; causes painful, heavy menses
  • Leiomyoma (fibroids):  benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterine myometrium; causes heavy, prolonged bleeding
  • Malignancy and hyperplasia (endometrial hyperplasia/cancer):  uncontrolled endometrial proliferation; causes irregular and/or heavy bleeding

Nonstructural causes: COEIN



  • Coagulopathy (eg, von Willebrand disease, thrombocytopenia):  results in heavy bleeding
  • Ovulatory dysfunction:  anovulation or irregular ovulation (eg, polycystic ovary syndrome [PCOS], thyroid disorder, hypothalamic amenorrhea); causes amenorrhea or irregular menses
  • Endometrial:  disorders that affect the endometrial lining (eg, endometritis, intrauterine adhesions); causes irregular bleeding
  • Iatrogenic:  medications that can cause abnormal bleeding (eg, contraceptive pills or devices, anticoagulants)
  • Not yet classified:  causes that do not fit into the previous categories

Evaluation

History



AUB can usually be further divided into subcategories based on history and physical examination.  In addition to menstrual history, findings in the patient's medical history can help in the diagnosis, including:



  • Medical history:  underlying medical conditions, surgeries, and medications
  • Obstetric history:  causes of AUB that also cause pregnancy complications such as preterm labor, recurrent pregnancy loss, and postpartum hemorrhage
  • Family history:  evaluation for bleeding disorders and genetic mutations that increase the risk for malignancy (eg, Lynch syndrome)

Physical examination



Physical examination should evaluate for signs of anemia, thyroid disease, and hyperandrogenism.  Pelvic examination should confirm that the bleeding is uterine in origin.  The uterus should be palpated for size, contour, tenderness, and mobility.  The adnexa should be palpated for masses and tenderness.



  • An irregular uterine contour or enlarged uterus suggests uterine leiomyoma.
  • A tender, boggy uterus suggests adenomyosis.
  • A tender, immobile uterus suggests endometriosis.

Laboratory evaluation



Basic laboratory evaluation of all patients with AUB includes:



  • Pregnancy test
  • Complete blood count to quantify blood loss and evaluate for anemia
  • Serum TSH, FSH, and prolactin levels to evaluate for hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis abnormalities, which cause anovulation


In some patients, additional testing can include:



  • Coagulation studies if a bleeding disorder is suspected
  • Serum testosterone and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate levels if no signs of hyperandrogenism are present

Imaging



In all gynecologic conditions, the most common imaging modality is transvaginal ultrasonography, which can evaluate the endometrium, myometrium, and adnexa for structural abnormalities.  In some patients with suspected pathology in the uterine cavity, sonohysterography (

), in which the uterine cavity is filled with a saline infusion, is used to better visualize intrauterine structures (eg, endometrial polyp, leiomyoma).

Management



Most cases of AUB, regardless of the etiology, are managed with a similar goal of menstrual regulation to improve the patient's quality of life and to prevent complications (eg, endometrial cancer, anemia).



This is most commonly accomplished medically with contraceptive options, including:



  • Combined estrogen/progestin oral contraceptive pills:  regulate endometrial thickness and shedding
  • Progestin-only contraception (including implants, intrauterine devices, or intramuscular injections):  decreases the endometrial lining
  • GnRH agonists (eg, leuprolide):  decrease the release of FSH and LH, resulting in amenorrhea.  Typically used only as a bridging therapy prior to surgical management in patients with heavy menstrual bleeding to improve anemia.


Patients whose condition does not improve with medical therapy are offered surgical management with:



  • Endometrial ablation (
    figure 2
    ):  typically used in patients with heavy menstrual bleeding without intrauterine pathology; surgically obliterates the endometrium to prevent menses
  • Myomectomy:  removal of uterine fibroids to decrease the endometrial surface area
  • Uterine artery embolization (
    figure 3
    ):  decreases blood flow to the uterus but preferentially decreases blood flow to uterine fibroids
  • Hysterectomy:  definitive management

Summary



Abnormal uterine bleeding is a common gynecologic condition related to uterine bleeding that is irregular in volume, duration, or timing.  Causes are both structural and nonstructural in nature; medical management of most causes involves the goal of menstrual regulation.
